Salem, Massachusetts - City Government is sharing a COVID-19 Update.
August 14 at 3:33 PM ¬∑

Commonwealth‚Äôs ‚ÄúStop the Spread‚Äù COVID-19 Testing Comes to #SalemMA

Free tests for Salem residents and workers offered August 17th through September 12th

Salem residents and workers can receive free COVID-19 testing as part of the state‚Äôs ‚ÄúStop the Spread‚Äù initiative. Testing will be offered six days a week starting Monday, August 17th via drive-through or walk-up outside of Salem High School at 77 Willson Street. Testing days and hours are as follows:

-Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays from 2:00 p.m. to 6:00 p.m.
-Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Saturdays from 10:00 a.m. to 2:00 p.m.

No proof of insurance or citizenship is necessary. Testing is via nasal swab, administered by EMTs from Fallon Ambulance, and processed via RT PCR at the Broad Institute Laboratory. Test results are returned, whether positive or negative, to the resident within 36 hours.

This testing replaces the previously announced Salem Coronavirus Awareness Network (SCAN) tests. SCAN testing dates will be rescheduled to dates later this fall with precise details being announced in the coming weeks.

In a ‚ÄúSummer of no good choices‚Äù And after 5 hours of discussion and public comment, the Salem School Committee voted 5-2 to adopt the proposed age-based reopening planning with conditions for reopening as amended during the meeting.

We appreciate the thoughtful conversation that has taken place leading up to this vote - every thought, question, and feeling is valid. We pledge to work closely with staff and families as we move into reopening planning and just as we have throughout this process, we will flex with input and data.

The final plan will be submitted to DESE on Friday with slight updates based on feedback. The plan is available in English, Spanish, and Portuguese and tomorrow the conditions for reopening will be posted in all languages.

Applications for transportation are now available on the website and have been mailed to all students who rode the bus in the 2019-20 school year.

Applications are due this Friday, July 31, 2020.

Please read the information carefully before sending in your application.

Due to limited capacity on buses to ensure physical distancing, we are asking that families only apply for transportation if they truly have no other way to get to school. In addition, bus routes may result in early arrivals at school and late pickups, in order to accommodate extra routes. Students will be supervised during that time.

If you have any questions, please call the transportation office at 978-740-1240.

Books available at food distribution sites for grades K-8!

March is National Nutrition Month

Farm to School

Did you know that in addition to providing nutritious meals that are mostly cooked from scratch (even homemade pasta!), that SPS students at Collins and SHS enjoy locally grown produce such as kale, squash, radishes, cucumbers, and carrots ten months out of the year? FNS participates in the National Farm to School Program which forms partnerships between school districts and local farms. SPS currently partners with Appleton Farms in Ipswich, but is looking to add partner farms to bring local produce to all of the Salem schools.

To demonstrate their commitment to healthy school meals, Deb and Irv will join the School Nutrition Association in D.C. next week to advocate for keeping the nutrition standards set by the Healthy Hunger Free Kids Act of 2010.

Today is Dominican Republic Independence Day. Here at Salem Public Schools, we honor our Dominican families who are celebrating today with a few facts!

The country was discovered in 1492 by Christopher Columbus and named La Hispaniola.

Juan Pablo Duarte, founder of the secret society La Trinitaria that ultimately freed the country of Haitian rule in 1844, is considered the founding father. He even has a public holiday January 26 ‚Äì Duarte Day.

Thousands of Dominicanos gather in Santo Domingo for the traditional parade and street fiesta throughout the day.

The island nation is slightly more than twice the size of New Hampshire. It shares a land boundary of 376 km with Haiti.

Here in Salem, there will be a flag-raising ceremony at Lafayette Park at 5pm on Friday, February 28th

Please join us tonight at 6:00 p.m. in the library at Saltonstall as we meet the third candidate for superintendent, Dr. Stephen Zrike, Jr.

Dr. Zrike is currently the Superintendent/Receiver of the Holyoke (MA) Public Schools. Prior to accepting the position in Holyoke, he served as Superintendent of the Wakefield (MA) Public Schools. Dr. Zrike has also held the position of Chief of Elementary Schools for the Chicago Public Schools, as well as Turnaround Principal of the Blackstone Elementary School, Principal of the Ohrenberger Elementary School and the Philbrick School, each in the Boston Public Schools. He was also a Teacher Leader in the Andover Public Schools. Dr. Zrike earned an Ed.D. and an Ed.M. degree in Administration, Planning, and Social Policy from Harvard University, and his B.A. degree in History from Dartmouth College.
